_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Para-Chem site is located on a 130-acre parcel of land near Simpsonville (Greenville County), South Carolina. Para-Chem produces acrylic polymers through water-based emulsion polymerization reactions. This process utilizes a number of chemicals as raw materials, three of which are listed as toxics under 40 CFR 68.130:   acrylonitrile, vinyl acetate, and aqueous ammonia.  Less than 2% of a fourth listed compound, formaldehyde, is a residual reactant in a monomer, N-methylolacrylamide.  Two of these chemicals, acrylonitrile and vinyl acetate monomer, are present in quantities above the threshold limits set forth for the RMP program. Furthermore, the process in which these chemicals are used is listed under SIC code 2821, making Para-Chem subject to level 3 program requirements.

Acrylonitrile is handled and stored as a non-refrigerated liquid. Effects of acute exposure to high concentrations of acrylonitrile include irritation of the respiratory tract experienced as nasal discomfort and discharge, with chest pain, coughing, headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and drowsiness. At high doses acrylonitrile can be fatal by inhalation, ingestion, skin contact and other routes. The threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR 68.130 for acrylonitrile is 20,000 lb. Para-Chem uses acrylonitrile as a raw material in an emulsion polymerization reaction and stores a quantity greater than the threshold amount in its monomer tank farm. Para-Chem has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of this material in the last five years.

Vinyl acetate monomer is handled and stored as a non-refrigerated liquid. Effects of acute exposure to high concentrations of vinyl acetate monomer include irritation of the respiratory tract experienced as nasal discomfort and discharge, with chest pain, coughing, headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and drowsiness. Liquid or vapor may cause irritation of the eyes experienced as stinging, excess blinking and tear production, with e

xcess redness in the conjunctiva. At high doses vinyl acetate can be fatal by inhalation, ingestion, skin contact and other routes. The RMP threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR 68.130 for vinyl acetate monomer is 15,000 lb. Para-Chem uses vinyl acetate as a raw material in an emulsion polymerization reaction and stores
a quantity greater than the threshold amount in its monomer tank farm.  Para-Chem has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of this material in the last five years.

Ammonia is also handled and stored as a non-refrigerated, aqueous liquid. Effects of acute exposure to high concentrations of ammonia include eye, mucous membrane and systemic irritation by inhalation. At high doses ammonia can be fatal by inhalation, ingestion, and possibly other routes. The threshold quantity for ammonia is 20,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]. Para-Chem uses aqueous solutions of ammonia in many of its
processes and stores 26 A?B?? (~29.5 wt%) aqueous ammonia in a horizontal tank. The aqueous ammonia has the following properties:

Aqua Ammonia Specifications
(Ref: Industrial Resources Group http://www.indresgroup.com/aqua_safety.htm)
Ammonia Content/Assay - 29.4% by weight
Density - 26 A? B??
Specific Gravity - 0.8974 @ 60 degrees F
Density - 7.48 lb/gal

The maximum quantity stored is less than the threshold quantity of 20,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]. Para-Chem has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of ammonia in the last five years.

Para-Chem uses 37% formaldehyde solution in the production processes in very small quantities, and the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for N-methylolacrylamide indicates that this monomer may contain a maximum of 2% formaldehyde by weight. N-methylolacrylamide is stored in a tank. The maximum amount of formaldehyde stored with N-methylolacrylamide and as formaldehyde solution at Para-Chem is less than the threshold quantity of 15,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]. Para-Chem has not had an accident

or incident
involving a reportable quantity of formaldehyde in the last five years.

Para-Chem does not designate employees for response other than to address incidental releases of hazardous substances where:
A? the substance can be absorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees in
the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel or A? clean-up a spill that does not pose an immediate safety or health hazard.
These actions are not considered response under OSHA or Part 68; therefore, Para-Chem is a A?nonresponding facilityA? [40 CFR 68.90(b)].  For A?non-responding facilitiesA?, EPA has adopted a policy similar to OSHA in its Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) [29 CFR 1910.120]. This allows these facilities to develop an emergency action plan to ensure employee safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response plan provided that they coordinate with local response agencies to ensure that they will be prepared to respond to an emergency at the facility.

Para-Chem operates in a manner that attempts to minimize hazards associated with the handling of chemicals. Para-Chem has several mechanisms in place for addressing a release of a regulated hazardous substance. These include the following:
A? A Spill Contingency Plan that documents the emergency contacts
A? An employee safety manual
A? ISO 9001 Procedures for unloading railcars and tank trucks
A? A severe weather plan

The Spill Contingency Plan that was developed in conjunction with the Process Hazard Analysis for the Polymer Manufacturing Process contains detailed information relating to materials stored on site, potential failures of equipment, and methods for containing or cleaning up lost materials. Manufacturing activities are discussed and chemicals are grouped with regard to their physical properties. Emergency contacts are identified and a notification procedure is detailed.
A? All plant-operating personnel are required to notify their

immediate supervisor in the event of an emergency.
A? The supervisor will then contact the plant Emergency Coordinator (EC).
A? The Emergency Coordinator will contact the appropriate local response organizations and, as necessary,
state and federal agencies.
A? A call list designating these contacts.

In the event of severe weather, Para-Chem is dedicated to protecting its employees and the surrounding community. Procedures have been set up to warn plant employees and shut down key operations in order to minimize material loss in the event of a weather related failure. The severe weather procedure is available for review at the site.

Para-Chem regularly receives shipments of vinyl acetate in tank trucks and transfers these materials into storage tanks located in one of several tank farms with secondary containment. The tank trucks are parked in secondary containment areas located by each tank farm and unloaded by trained personnel. Para-Chem has  a documented ISO-9001 procedure for these operators to follow.  During delivery, the vapor in the headspace of these tanks is vented back to the delivering tanker.  Para-Chem regularly receives shipments of acrylonitrile in railcars and transfers these materials into storage tanks located in one of several tank farms with secondary containment. The railcars are parked in designated unloading areas near the tank farm and are unloaded by trained personnel. Para-Chem has a documented ISO-9001 procedure for these operators to follow.  Normal breathing losses from the acrylonitrile and vinyl acetate storage tanks are vented through conservation vents to a thermal oxidizer.

Para-Chem controls the emissions of the odorous acrylate esters, vinyl acetate, and acrylonitrile with two thermal oxidizers operated interchangeably; usage is rotated between the two units.  Breathing losses from the monomer storage tanks, emissions from the weigh tanks, and emissions from the reactors are collected in separate manifolds for treatment in th

e thermal oxidizer.

It is Para-Chem's training philosophy that all employees will be trained to perform their assigned duties safely and effectively. To this end, ISO procedures were created to provide work instructions and training documentation tools for effectively and systematically planning training initiatives, assessing training needs,providing required employee training, and maintaining appropriate training records. 

In order to ensure an efficient workplace, preventive maintenance is performed on a majority of the equipment at Para-Chem. These procedures are documented and a copy of the related ISO procedure is available for review at the site.  Para-Chem has established a Management of Change procedure so that formulation, process, or equipment modifications and installations are reviewed prior to implementation to assure that safety issues are appropriately addressed, changes are communicated, and documentation is updated.

Para-Chem occasionally brings in outside contractors for specific tasks. Any contractor that is performing work in the manufacturing facility is given a safety briefing that includes:
A? Emergency Evacuation Plan
A? Location of Fire Extinguishers, Fire Exits, and Eye Wash/Shower Stations
A? Location of Material Safety Data Sheet
A? Location of Safety Manuals
A? Specific Hazards Workers May be Exposed To
A? Use of Personal Protective Equipment
A? Requirements of Hot-Work Permits
A? Use and Storage of any Flammable Liquids
A? Location of any Underground Utility Lines
A? Manner of Conduct
A? Other related information
